1st Endorsement.

Army Medical Museum
Washington DC. Sept. 9, 1902.

Respectfully forwarded to the Sur-
geon General, U. S. A. This applicati-
on meets with my most earnest ap-
proval. Dr. James Carroll, Contract
Surgeon U. S. A., has been closely asso-
ciated with me in daily professio-
nal work since October, 1893, during
which time he has served in the
capacity of Assistant Instructor in
the Army Medical School, as assis-
tant in laboratory work and as my
colleague on the Yellow Fever Board
appointed by Par. 34, S.O.N: 122, A.G.
O., May 24, 1900. In each of these capa-
cities he has not only discharged his
obligations to the U. S. Government in
a most faithful and intelligent man-
ner, but has also demonstrated courage
of a high order in submitting himself
to inoculation for the purpose of
proving the mosquito - theory of yellow
fever. I know of no physician who de-
serves more credit than Dr. Carroll for
his intelligent perseverance in
rising from the grade of an enlis-
ted soldier through that of non-
commissioned officer to the rank
of Contract Surgeon U. S. A., in all
of which grades his record has been
continually excellent. He has, by
constant application to his studies
and duties, won the hearty esteem
both of his senior medical officers
of the Faculty of the Army Medical
School as well as that of the best phy-
sicians in the city of Washington,
and I am pleased to add that his
desire to enter the service as a
commissioned medical officer meets
with the hearty approval of all the
members of the Faculty of the Army
Medical School. I, therefore, earn-
estly recommend that Dr. Carrolls
application may receive favor-
able action

Walter Reed,
Major, Surgeon U. S. A.
2 Enclosures

2d Indorsement
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE.
September 11, 1902.

Respectfully forwarded to
the ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE
ARMY, with request that these
papers be submitted to the Hon.
the Secretary of War.

This is an application from
Dr. James Carroll, Contract Sur-
geon, U. S. Army, for an invita-
tion to appear before the Army
Medical Board now in session
for examination with a view to
appointment as Assistant Surgeon
in the Army should he be found
qualified.

Dr. Carroll's long service
has been so useful and brilliant
that his request would be grant-
as a matter of course but for
the fact that he is 48 years old
and so is barred out by the
present regulation on the sub-
ject. This regulation can how-
ever be waived by the Hon. the
Secretary of War, and consider-
ing that Dr. Carroll has already
spent twenty-four years of his
life in the military service as
an enlisted man and later as a
contract surgeon, I believe the
regulation should be waived so
far as it applies to him.

Attention is invited to
the enclosed commendations and
to the endorsements hereon.

I recommend that Dr. Car-
roll be authorized to appear
